section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity you will need 20 Connecting Cubes to serve as “teeth.”

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Dentists and What They Do, we learned that we all start with 20 baby teeth!
In this activity, we will count around the circle like we did earlier today. This time, each time you count a number, you will reach into the center and pick a “tooth.”

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place 20 Connecting Cubes in the center of the table. Have children count with you as you place each cube in the center. How many teeth in all?

Count Off Invite a child to start the count by picking up one Connecting Cube from the pile and holding it while saying the number. Direct the next child to continue the count, picking up another “tooth” to hold. Repeat until the group reaches 20, and there are no more “teeth” in the pile.

Extend Ask, How many teeth are there in all? Guide children to count the “teeth” again, this time counting all the teeth in a child’s hand before moving on to the next child. Do we still have 20 teeth when we count this way?

Talk About Teeth Invite children to hold up their Connecting Cube “teeth.” Wow! That’s a lot of teeth! Explain that their 20 baby teeth will eventually fall out and be replaced by up to 32 adult teeth! Ask, Has anyone lost a tooth yet? How did it feel?
Keep the pace slow, and encourage children to use their fingers as a support. Use 10 Connecting Cubes and let children know they are counting only their top or bottom “teeth.”
Instead of having children count around the circle, point to children randomly and ask them count the next number.

Review numbers 1–20 and key vocabulary, such as baby teeth, with children. Keep the pace slow. If necessary, repeat the previous number and provide the first syllable of the child’s number: fourteen, fi
. (fifteen)
Have children draw teeth as playing pieces for this activity. They can glue the teeth into a “mouth” as they say their numbers.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64928-4. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need about 20 Pattern Blocks: 10 squares and 10 triangles.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Dentists and What They Do, we talked about how it is important for dentists to be kind to their patients and for patients to listen to their dentists.
In this activity, we will act out a visit to the dentist with a partner. One partner will be the dentist and count tools, and the other partner will be the patient and practice brushing their teeth.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Introduce Ask children to find a partner and decide who will be the dentist and who will be the patient. Encourage the dentist and patient to introduce themselves as if at a dentist’s appointment.

The Dentist’s Job Ask the dentist to count one set of two tools: Take two squares. Then, ask the dentist to count a second set of two tools: Now, take two triangles. Ask, Do you have the same number of triangle tools as you have square tools? How can you tell?

The Patient’s Job Ask the patients to count as they practice brushing their teeth. Brush for 20 seconds. Let’s count! They can use a finger to pretend to make the motion of brushing teeth as they count. Encourage dentists to count along with patients as they pretend to brush.
Switch Roles Have children switch roles. Ask the new dentists to count three tools in each set, and patients to brush for 25 seconds.

Talk About the Dentist Talk about what it was like to be the dentist and the patient. Why was it important to introduce yourselves before the appointment? When else is it important to introduce yourself?

Count each set of tools along with the dentists. Guide them to understand that even though the tools are different, they still have the same amount in each set. Ask patients to brush their teeth for 10 seconds or less.
Have dentists count a higher number of square tools, and ask: Can you count the same number of triangles? You may also use three types of tools, and ask for equal quantities of each.

This activity may be challenging for multilingual learners—they will need to use vocabulary to introduce themselves, as well as number names to count. Model simple introductions for children to follow, use sentence clozes as necessary, and review the number names before beginning the activity.

Invite partners to sit on the floor next to the table for their “appointment,” in whatever position is most comfortable for them. You may also wish to draw tools in black and white for children to use as playing pieces for this activity, as the bright colors of Pattern Blocks may overstimulate children with sensory needs.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64928-4. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity you will need a pencil to use as a pointer and 20 Connecting Cubes to serve as “teeth.”

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Dentists and What They Do, we counted the items we saw in different orders.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review the Vocabulary Let’s review the word order. Use the order Vocabulary Card to reteach the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will use Connecting Cubes as “teeth” to count. Everyone will count the “teeth” in a different order.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: aSet Up Set up 20 Connecting Cubes as though they were a set of teeth, with one equal set on top of the other.
Count Give one child the pointer. Say, Use the pointer to count each tooth. Let’s start with this tooth! Guide the child to count each tooth. Ask, How many teeth are there in all?

Repeat Give another child the pointer. This time, have the child start with a different tooth and count in the opposite direction. Ask, How many teeth are there in all? Repeat until every child has had a turn, changing the first tooth counted each time and always asking, How many in all?

Talk About Counting Talk about counting the teeth in different orders. Ask, Was the number of teeth different when [child’s name] counted the teeth? How about when [child’s name] counted? How could you tell? Does it matter which tooth we count first?

Start with 10 Connecting Cubes. Model counting the “teeth,” showing children how to use the pointer to count each tooth. Have children move each cube to the side as they count it to prevent counting the same cube twice.

Invite children to choose where they start counting teeth. Encourage them to start with a tooth that has not yet been counted first. You may also mix the teeth around after each child counts, so that the Connecting Cubes themselves are in different orders each time.

In Spanish, baby teeth are sometimes called dientes de leche, which translates to “milk teeth.” If children use this phrase, explain that in Spanish they are sometimes called that because of the color of the teeth, and not because they are made out of milk. Then repeat that in English, we call the same teeth “baby teeth.”
Spread the “teeth” across a larger area, either on the floor or across tables. Have children walk or hop to each tooth as they count aloud.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64928-4. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Keep Your Hands Clean, we learned a song to help us wash our hands. Singing the song takes about 20 seconds, which is how long we should scrub and rinse our hands. We can wash our hands even longer than that if we like!

I’m going to pretend to wash my hands and count to 20. But I need you to listen carefully! Sometimes I don’t pay close enough attention when I wash my hands, and I skip a number. If I forget to count a number, raise your hand to let me know!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Wash Your Hands Pretend to scrub your hands while you count aloud to 20. Remember, hold up your hand if I make a mistake! As you count, skip one of the numbers and keep counting. Stop counting when the first hand goes up. Ask, What number did I skip? Guide children to continue counting from where you stopped.
Repeat Repeat, skipping a different number each time.

Talk About Counting Invite children to pretend to scrub their hands with you, and count chorally to 20 without skipping any numbers. Then, discuss what it was like to listen for mistakes. How could you tell when I had skipped a number? Was it difficult to remember what number came next?
Count at a slow pace so that children have time to recognize when you have omitted a number. Choose a number below 10 to skip, as children will be more familiar with counting 1–9.
Make different mistakes, sometimes skipping more than one number at a time (7, 19) or adding in non-numerals (1, blue, 3). Alternately, do this activity while counting backward.
Review numbers 1–20 and key vocabulary words, such as scrub and rinse. Count slowly, and always recount correctly to reinforce the correct order.
Children who have trouble staying still or focusing can be given an object to hold in one hand, such as a stress ball, that they can squeeze as they listen to you count.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64928-4. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
